title-group.article-title: Computational analysis of the effects of a boundary layer ingesting propulsion system in transonic flow

abstract.p: Continuous requirements for more efficient aircrafts lead to the design and analysis of novel propulsion configurations, with an example being the boundary layer ingestion. The complexity and integration challenges in such aircraft synergistic propulsion system characterize the research in this field, driven by the potential benefits. The aim of this article is to investigate the effects of boundary layer ingestion on the aerodynamics of a transonic wing, together with the quality of the flow ingested by the propulsion system. A two-dimensional computational model of a transonic airfoil with boundary layer ingesting propulsion system is developed in order to assess boundary layer ingestion for a commercial air transport at cruise conditions and highlight the complex integration issues arising from such configuration. A parametric analysis of the effects of flight conditions, nacelle geometry and engine operating point, on lift, pressure recovery, distortion, total pressure and velocity distribution at the intake, comes to enhance understanding of the performance of this configuration. The pressure distribution around the airfoil and the boundary layer growth are both substantially affected by the engine operating condition, which is represented by the mass flow ratio, with a direct impact on pressure recovery and lift. Mach number and angle of attack influences on lift and drag ingested are also investigated. Intake size and position on the airfoil appear to have significant effects on lift and losses ingested. In general, the results of this study include several aspects related to wing aerodynamics and ingested flow quality, which may facilitate design and integration of the boundary layer ingestion propulsion system for future commercial aircraft.

sec.title: Introduction
sec.p: The benefits of ingesting the boundary layer developed by the viscosity on the aircraft fuselage and then re-energizing it through the engine were first discussed in 1930s. Darrieus1 proposed an aircraft with a propeller installed at the aft of the fuselage, accelerating the flow to a velocity close to the flying one. In addition, he suggested the use of a row of small propellers along the wing trailing edge, something that appears to be the first distributed propulsion system. The benefits of boundary layer ingestion (BLI) were later discussed by Kuchemann and Weber,2 who also proposed a synergistic propulsion system; the jet-wing with buried engines in the wing.3 Nowadays, all these concepts are revisited under the pressure for step change in efficiency improvements.

Some of these benefits were quantitatively assessed by Smith4 who performed a detailed study of boundary layer suction through slots, reducing friction drag. The main results based on test data show that the boundary layer suction engines have better control characteristics, higher lift (CL) and lift over drag ratio (L/D), shorter runway length required, higher maximum speed and a 5%–10% of reduction in fuel consumption at cruise. A later study5 using actuator disk theory, incompressible flow and no mixing revealed maximum benefits in the region of 7%, concluding that the propeller should be sized to ingest as much boundary layer as possible but not extra flow. A more exhaustive study on the performance of a BLI propulsion system was recently performed by Plas et al.6 The BLI benefits appeared to be sensitive to duct and fan losses. For the SAX40 aircraft designed by Silent Aircraft Initiative, the ingested drag reduced drag coefficient by 16.6%, while pressure recovery of the intakes was estimated at about 0.94% and a 3.8% fuel burn savings were calculated. In general, BLI is linked to two opposite trends: an increase in propulsive efficiency; and a decrease in cycle efficiency due to inlet distortion. However, in all cases, a good potential for fuel savings is shown.

As discussed above,6 the inlet total pressure loss and distortion has a direct impact on engine efficiency and thus on fuel consumption. In this direction, Anabtawi et al.7 carried out experimental investigations of boundary layer ingesting diffusers with a flat plate upstream, founding a pressure recovery of around 94% and a distortion of DC(60) = 63%. Moreover, it was shown that the use of vortex generators (VGs) can reduce distortion. Similar pressure recovery of around 94% was found by Berrier and Allan,8 who compared experimental and computational results of flush mounted S-duct inlets with BLI. Distortion reduction in BLI intakes using active flow control or VGs was assessed by Owens et al.9 as well as Ferrar et al.10 All these studies show the complexity of the BLI inlet design.

In spite of the complexity of propulsion system and aircraft integration, BLI is a proposed configuration in several future commercial aircraft concepts due to its potential efficiency improvement. Callaghan and Liebeck11 and Liebeck et al.12 presented a novel aircraft configuration using BLI with improving efficiency, fuel burnt, lift over drag, total thrust required, volume, weight, noise, etc., which are similar results to the above in Smith and Roberts.4 Design and experimental testing of a blended wing body (BWB) aircraft with BLI was described in Campbell et al.13 performing an intake optimization14,15 and getting accurate computational fluid dynamics (CFD) correlations of moments, forces and wing pressure.

It should be mentioned that BLI benefits are enhanced when combined with distributed propulsion, due to large coverage of the wing span, which leads to a large amount of boundary layer ingested. Potential advantages in aircraft efficiency and fuel consumption using distributed propulsion together with BLI were discussed in Sehra and Whitlow.16 A comparison of different numbers of distributed engines with BLI was carried out by Lundbladh and Grönstedt,17 who treated the ingested boundary layer as ingested drag, according to Smith.5 Taking into account pressure losses and engine scaling effects, savings in fuel consumption were found. Similar results were found in an optimization study of an aircraft with distributed BLI propulsion system performed by Kok et al.;18 however, additional pressure losses were found to reduce the benefits dramatically in some cases. In order to overcome the engine scaling effects issue,17 NASA proposed fans driven by superconducting electrical motors and studied a BWB aircraft with BLI distributed fans under a common nacelle.19,20 New possibilities for aircraft and fan configurations were discussed showing the requirement of a very thorough propulsion and airframe integration analysis. Additionally, it has been shown that the quality and features of the ingested flow have a substantial impact on the benefits from BLI. For this reason, part of this study focuses on the analysis of the parameters that affect the ingested flow features as well as the effects of BLI on wing aerodynamics for integrating purposes.

From the existing literature, it can be concluded that BLI bears the potential of increasing propulsive efficiency and reducing fuel consumption. Nonetheless, certain challenges arise in relation to the installation on the aircraft of a coupled synergistic lift-propulsive system and to a highly distorted flow entering the engine. In order to shed some light in this area, article includes a preliminary parametrical analysis of a supercritical airfoil with BLI. Effects of the mass flow ratio (MFR), Mach number, angle of attack and geometrical parameters on the aerodynamic performance of the aircraft wing as well as characteristics of the flow ingested by the engines are analysed numerically in transonic flow using as a tool, a two-dimensional (2D) CFD model of a wing airfoil with an BLI engine at the aft. This study clarifies the behaviour of relevant variables as ingested flow distortion, intake pressure recovery, lift, equivalent ingested drag, velocity and total pressure, which are related to propulsive efficiency, thermal efficiency, aircraft lift and drag, as these are the main objectives involved in aircraft propulsion system design.

sec.title: Problem configuration
sec.p:
A propulsion system is studied in this article for a BWB aircraft with distributed engines under a common nacelle embedded in the upper rear part of the wing ingesting the boundary layer developed over the airframe (Figure 1). The little variation between the sections of the BWB aircraft with distributed engines allows a 2D study to be close to reality. Thus, a 2D section of the BWB aircraft with BLI at cruise conditions is investigated using a CFD model. Engine cycle boundary conditions are set at the intake throat and nozzle exit planes. Figure 1.
Configuration of a BWB aircraft with distributed propulsion and BLI.

sec.title: Propulsive efficiency and thermal efficiency using BLI
sec.p: The implementation of BLI makes possible to improve propulsive efficiency beyond the engine size restrictions of conventional turbofans. Improvements in propulsive efficiency results in reduction in fuel consumption, equation (3). The propulsive efficiency, ηprop, is defined as the ratio of useful energy over kinetic energy given to the flow by the engine (1)ηprop=ΔEusefulΔEkinetic=T·V0Ekinetic,out-Ekinetic,in

The improvement in propulsive efficiency comes as a result of the engine ingesting flow at lower than flight velocity. The engine is, therefore, working with the same momentum addition for the same thrust as for a standard aircraft, but at a lower kinetic energy difference. As a result, the useful energy term T · V0 can be higher in relation to the kinetic energy added by the engine, thus decreasing the wasted energy left in the wake.21 The propulsive efficiency equation can be written, as proposed in Mantic-Lugo,21 but also in Felder et al.20 in the following form (2)ηprop=T·V0Ekinetic,out-Ekinetic,in=(Vj-V01)·V01 2Vj 2-1 2V01 2=2VjV0+V01V0 where V0 is the flying velocity, V01 the mass flow average ingestion velocity at free-stream static pressure p0, V01 < V0, and Vj the mass flow average jet velocity. This simple new equation is conservative, which means that the real propulsive efficiency benefits using BLI are even a bit higher than the one given by this equation. The mass flow averaged ingested flow velocity at free-stream static pressure V01 is directly related to the equivalent drag ingested produced by the losses in the boundary layer,5 see Appendix 2. Hence, the detailed assessment of the equivalent drag ingested directly linked to V01 is crucial for the system efficiency evaluation as well as for a thorough and clear aircraft drag accounting, which is in general complex for this strongly coupled propulsion system.

The engine thermal efficiency is directly related to the fan efficiency, with the intake flow distortion having a direct negative effect on it. This is significant for a BLI propulsion system as the ingestion of boundary layer entails an intake flow distortion. Thus, accounting of the ingested flow quality is crucial as the benefits in fuel consumption due to propulsion efficiency improvements can be eradicated by the reduction of engine thermal efficiency since fuel consumption is inversely proportional to propulsive and thermal efficiencies as (3)TSFC∝1ηth·ηprop

sec.title: Airfoil selection
sec.p: This study is focused on transonic flows; therefore, a suitable airfoil is required. In addition, as the BLI system is placed at the upper airfoil aft, it is required that the shock wave is not positioned close to the airfoil rear part like in general supercritical airfoils, because this would entail very strong interactions between the pre-compression region upstream the engine and the shock wave, yielding very strong separation.

The airfoil RAE 2822 is selected due to its wide use as validation case for CFD models in the transonic region in addition to its suitable shock wave position at transonic flight. RAE 2822 is a 12% thick supercritical airfoil with a moderate amount of aft loading, while it was tested experimentally in the RAE 8 × 6 ft transonic wind tunnel.22

sec.title: Flying conditions
sec.p: In order to ensure applicability of the present results, flight conditions were chosen to match an aircraft at cruise condition. Chosen cruise conditions at the tropopause for a standard static atmosphere and a cruise Mach number M = 0.73 are summarized in Table 1. The airfoil chord size selected is 10 m, which yields a Reynolds number of Re ≃ 50 · 106 based on the chord and the cruise flying conditions, which is in the order of the Re of a typical commercial aircraft. For the validation of the CFD model, a 1 m chord airfoil is created to match the Reynolds number of the experiments, Re = 6.5 · 106.22

sec.title: Geometry
sec.p: As indicated above, the airfoil RAE2822 is used as the body with the engine nacelle located at the rear upper part of the airfoil ingesting the boundary layer developed over the upper surface. Only the upper side of the nacelle is designed since the lower side is the airfoil surface. In this sense, the design does not change the aft camber of the lower airfoil surface minimizing the effects of the engine on the lift.

sec.title: Nacelle definition
sec.p:
The nacelle is divided into forebody and afterbody with no midbody, for minimizing length. The main geometrical variables defining the 2D nacelle for a BLI aircraft are depicted in Figure 2. Figure 2.
Simple nacelle geometry definition.

sec.title: Forebody
sec.p:
A NACA-1 series external cowl is used for the forebody due to its widespread acceptance. Its geometry is defined by the dimensional parameters Hh, Hmax and Lf. Drag rise Mach number, MD, and critical MFR, MFRcrit, define the performance of the nacelle, the onset of significant spillage drag and wave drag. The operating conditions need to be in a safe region, assuring that MFR is higher than MFRcrit and free-stream Mach number is lower than MD. In the case of BLI, the values of the Mach number that the intake cowl located over the airfoil perceives are different from the free-stream Mach number. In addition, the MFR, defined in equation (12), does not represent the real contraction of the streamtube in front of the intake. Thus, the values of MD and MFRcrit selected have to be in a very safe region. MD and MFRcrit are correlated with cowl main geometrical parameters.23 These correlations are adapted from axisymmetric correlations as follows (4)MFRcrit= (1-4(1-Hh/Hmax)2Lf/(2Hmax) )5 2
(5)MD=1-1 81-(Hh/Hmax)2Lf/(2Hmax) where Hh is the highlight height, Hmax the maximum height of the cowl and Lf the length of the forebody (Figure 2).

sec.title: Afterbody
sec.p:
For the afterbody, a circular-arc boattail profile is considered. The final boattail arc and the radius of the nacelle are calculated as (6)tan(βc)=Hmax-H9Laft
(7)βf=2βc
(8)Raft=Laftsin(βf) where H9 is the height of the nozzle, Laft the length of the afterbody, βc the chord angle, βf the final boattail angle and Raft the arc radius. The final boattail angle βf, Figure 2, needs to be the smallest possible in order to avoid separation and minimize the drag, being βf ≃ 16° the maximum typical values for a well-designed nacelle. A trade-off between the length and the boattail angle is required since the friction drag increases with afterbody length.

sec.title: Lip
sec.p:
An elliptic lip between the highlight, Hh, and the throat, Hth, is used. The relation between the semi-axes is (9)a=2b
(10)b=Hh-Hth where a is the length of the lip and b its height. The height of the lip b comes from the contraction ratio selected for the throat (11)Cr=AhAth=HhHth where Ah is the area at highlight and Ath the area of the throat.

sec.title: Nacelle design
sec.p: As the engine size and therefore the mass flow are not defined a priori, the nacelle geometry parameters are the free design variables. Defining the highlight height Hh and the nacelle total length Ltot = Lf + Laft, both of them are directly related to the upstream aerodynamics as they are related with the mass flow and the available airfoil surface for boundary layer development. The rest of the nacelle geometry parameters come from drag minimization. The selected nominal parameters are an intake highlight Hh = 0.3 m, 3% of the airfoil chord, and a nacelle total length Ltot = 1.7 m which is 17% of the body chord. Later, they are modified to assess their effects on the airfoil aerodynamics. The considered values of the geometric variables for the three different nacelle designs are summarized in Table 2.

sec.title: Airfoil and nacelle blending
sec.p: The nacelle is designed for a flow coming straight to the intake as in a free-stream flow. Then, it is rotated around the end of the afterbody to match the flow direction. The rotation angle is calculated to match the airfoil rear part angle of approximately 10°, as shown in Figure 3. It should also be noted that the final boattail angle for the rotated nacelle inherently includes the angle of rotation. This means that the boattail angle has to be less than 6°.

caption.p: Rotation of the nacelle. TE: trailing edge.

sec.title: Computational model
sec.p: The ANSYS CFX finite-volume implicitly coupled solver engine24 is used to carry out the numerical study of the BLI airfoil in a transonic flow. The compressible Reynolds-averaged Navier–Stokes (RANS) equations are solved using the high-resolution scheme and the two equation k–ω shear stress transport (SST) turbulence model over a structured mesh.21 Initially, a baseline case to validate the approach is run comparing the numerical results obtained with the experimental ones.22 In a second step, the airfoil with BLI model is created based on the clean baseline airfoil. The mesh is created using the ANSYS ICEM CFD25 and all the models are run as quasi-2D in CFX.24

sec.title: CFD mesh
sec.p: Using the guidelines provided in Mavriplis et al.26 a structured mesh is created. The distance from the airfoil to the side and upstream boundary is 15c and to the downstream boundary is 20c, c being the airfoil chord. This spacing is deemed to be enough to set the free-stream conditions for the far-field boundary.

The mesh is generated with node clustering for the boundary layer of the airfoil. The y+ is within the specified limits for solving the boundary layer using the k–ω SST turbulence model.24,26 In addition, in the direction perpendicular to the airfoil, a geometric growth rate of 1.2 is used for the nodes in the boundary layer, guaranteeing enough nodes inside the boundary layer.26 For the baseline case, the mesh is wrapped around the airfoil in a C-grid topology with 500 × 130 grid nodes, 300 nodes located over the airfoil and 200 in the wake region. For the airfoil with BLI, the C-grid topology has 540 × 140 grid nodes, 340 nodes located over the airfoil and nacelle, as shown in Figures 4 and 5. Additionally, a local C-grid around the intake lip is created to match the mesh around the engine with the large structured topology (Figure 6). The intake throat has 85 nodes and 75 nodes are used for the nacelle. An H-grid topology is created for the nozzle of the engine with 100 × 70 grid nodes in the wake region. The clustered node spacing of the boundary layer extended in the downstream direction is matched from the nozzle jet side, forming a double boundary layer. In Figure 6, this clustering of nodes in the mixing zone of the fast jet flow with the slow flow from the airfoil and nacelle surface enables the accurate calculation of the high-shear layer that appears there. For quasi-2D cases, as the present one, first, a planar mesh is created and then it is extruded to 3D, creating a quasi-2D domain of one element layer.24 Further details of the meshing and CFD model can be found in Mantic-Lugo.21 Figure 4.
Mesh of the whole domain.
Figure 5.
Mesh around the airfoil and engine.
Figure 6.
Mesh around the engine nacelle.

sec.title: CFD solver set-up and boundary conditions
sec.p: The transonic nature of the flow with shock waves requires the use of a second-order derivative approximation and energy equation. The turbulence model k–ω SST is selected, as mentioned previously, due to the good approximation of jet spreading rate.27

For the airfoil surface, a non-slip adiabatic smooth-wall boundary condition is used. The free stream is simulated as a subsonic inlet and outlet boundary condition. Changes in the angle of attack α are equivalent to changes in the flow direction. The flow direction is changed in the inlet boundary based on the Cartesian velocity components Vx = V0cos(α) and Vy = V0sin(α), which depend on the flying velocity V0 and the angle of attack α. In addition to the velocity components, the static temperature and a low turbulence intensity, 1%, are set. The outlet boundary condition of the domain is imposed using averaged static pressure. The nozzle boundary condition is modelled as a subsonic inlet condition with a given mass flow rate, static temperature and flow direction. For the engine fan inlet, a different approach is followed. The use of a mass flow boundary condition would induce unrealistic velocity profile as it does not allow for reverse flow at the intake plane. The static pressure is, therefore, a more appropriate boundary condition, enabling a more accurate calculation of the velocity profile at the highlight plane, as it enables the natural reverse flow that occurs at low engine MFRs.

For every case study, static pressure is varied to change the mass flow entering the engine. High MFR entails low static pressure and low MFR yields high static pressure. Hence, static pressure is the handling variable and the mass flow entering the engine is obtained a posteriori once the CFD model is converged. For the back-flow zone, the flow direction is set normal to the boundary and the static temperature the same as in the free-stream. The second-order RANS case is assumed to have converged when all root mean square (RMS) residuals fall at least four orders RMS ≤ 10−4, the monitored forces on the airfoil are stable with no oscillation and the imbalances of energy, mass and momentum are much smaller than 0.1%.

sec.title: CFD validation
sec.p:
As mentioned above, the CFD approach is validated with the airfoil RAE 2822 wind tunnel experiments run in the RAE 8 × 6 ft transonic wind tunnel.22 The wind tunnel test case 9 is selected, Mach number is 0.73 and Reynolds number based on the airfoil chord is Re = 6.5 · 106. The basic computational model is scaled to have an airfoil with 1 m chord for the validation case. The grid dependency of the solution is assessed creating three grids and comparing the results of these grids with the experiments. A medium grid already described, a coarser grid with one-fourth of the nodes and a finer grid with four times more nodes than in the medium grid are used. This comparison is used for the validation of the approach and as baseline for the next more complex cases analysed. The authors are aware that the accuracy of the turbulence model is not validated in detail for the flow features in the BLI study case, since an experimental comparison is not available. However, the wide spread use of k–ω SST turbulence model for engineering applications, together with the aim of this article to provide a physical view and a preliminary study of the parameters involved in the BLI engine–aircraft coupling, makes the CFD model far sufficient. Distributions of the pressure coefficient Cp obtained around the airfoil for the three grids and the experimental result are presented in Figure 7. The shock wave position is predicted accurately, being only a small difference between the fine and the medium meshes. The Cp slope in the shock wave zone rotates around one point for the three different meshes. A similar phenomenon was also mentioned in Mavriplis et al.26 The CFD results are compared with the experimental ones in Table 3. The difference in the angle of attack α for the same lift are within the reported experimental uncertainty of the Mach number and angle of attack due to wall interference.22 The drag relative error is 10%, which is acceptable, being in the order of results presented in Mavriplis et al.26 The variations of the drag and lift coefficients with the grid refinement are depicted in Figure 8. The lift and drag variations between the medium and fine grids are small, allowing the use of the medium grid for the calculations of the BLI propulsion system. Figure 7.
RAE2822 pressure coefficient Cp, M = 0.73, Re = 6.5 · 106, α = 3°.
Figure 8.
Lift CL (a) and drag CD (b) coefficient dependency with grid for M = 0.73, Re = 6.5 · 106 and α = 3°. CFD: computational fluid dynamics.

sec.title: Results and discussion
sec.p: The blended airfoil with the BLI propulsion system is modelled in 2D with a Reynolds number of Re ≃ 50 · 106. The flying conditions of the model detailed in Table 1 are used unless specified otherwise. MFR has a substantial influence on the flow field and it is representative of engine rating. For this reason, it is chosen as the main variable in all cases studied. The effects of the other parameters, such as angle of attack, Mach number, intake height and nacelle length are studied in combination with MFR modification. For every case study, the effects on lift, pressure recovery, distortion, total pressure at the intake and velocity distribution are analysed. The nominal values of the parameters are summarized in Table 4.

sec.title: MFR effects
sec.p: The MFR defined as (12)MFR=A0Ath=Wfanρ0V0Ath is based on the geometrical throat area Ath.

The effects of MFR on the wing in front of the engine for two very different MFRs are presented in Figure 9. Figure 9.
Mach contours for MFR influence on the flow upstream the engine, α = 2.6, M=0.73, nacelle 1. (a) Low MFR, 0.23; (b) High MFR, 0.84.

At low MFR, the boundary layer starts to grow at the shock wave base, exhibiting an extended boundary layer separation area in the pre-compression zone just in front of the engine. This is created by the large adverse pressure gradient due to high static pressure at the intake throat, increasing losses on the airfoil surface. As a result, low MFR creates flow spillage above the nacelle, decreasing system efficiency, as this low energy flow is not ingested. In addition, a shock wave appears over the intake due to the flow acceleration around the intake lip and forebody, giving rise to wave drag, thus increasing overall nacelle drag. Moreover, the spillage effect at low MFR is stronger in this configuration than in a conventional podded installation. The reason is that the flow can spill through only one side of the nacelle. Nacelle aerodynamics are, therefore, more sensitive to changes of MFR. Thus, extreme care should be taken on the design of the nacelle and BLI system.

At high MFR, a suction takes place upstream the engine, producing a favourable pressure gradient, which reduces the boundary layer thickness. In addition, the shock wave moves along the airfoil upper surface with MFR variation. Such condition has a beneficial effect on the airfoil lift, as shown in Figure 10. The lift developed can be even higher than for a plain airfoil with no BLI. The lift coefficient is defined as (13)CL=Lairfoil1 2ρ0V0 2Sref where reference surface Sref is equal to the no BLI airfoil surface, Sref = Chord × Span, Lairfoil the lift force on the airfoil surface, ρ0 the reference density and V0 the free-stream velocity. High MFR enhances the acceleration on the upper surface of the airfoil, thus producing more suction. Opposite behaviour occurs for decreasing MFR, where a strong pre-compression appears in front of the engine, reducing flow velocity over the airfoil and increasing static pressure at the upper surface of the airfoil, with a subsequent impact on the overall airfoil lift. Both of these effects are illustrated in Figure 11, where the pressure coefficient around the airfoil is depicted. Figure 10.
Lift coefficient with MFR. BLI: boundary layer ingestion; MFR: mass flow ratio.
Figure 11.
Variation of the pressure coefficient on the airfoil for different MFRs, α = 2.6, M = 0.73, nacelle 1. BLI: boundary layer ingestion; MFR: mass flow ratio.

The total pressure contours around the airfoil and engine are shown in Figure 12. The losses that are ingested can be seen as the total pressure losses ingested. Then, through the engine, total pressure increases by the momentum added by the propulsion system. It is worth noting that the total pressure losses at the upper surface are more intense than at the lower one. This is the result of adverse pressure gradient at the recompression zone. This phenomenon supports the choice of locating the BLI system at the suction side of the airfoil. Figure 12.
MFR influence on total pressure, α = 2.6, M = 0.73, nacelle 1. (a) Low MFR, 0.23; (b) High MFR, 0.84.

The boundary layer velocity and Mach number profiles at the intake throat plane are plotted in Figure 13. The boundary layer growth with decreasing MFR is of particular interest. At extremely low MFR, a recirculation region appears as a result of the adverse pressure gradient in the pre-compression zone. The Mach number and velocity profiles are almost identical since the temperature variation due to boundary layer losses is not large enough to affect the speed of sound. Figure 13.
Boundary layer velocity and Mach number profiles at the intake throat for different MFRs, α = 2.6, M = 0.73, nacelle 1. Notice that the velocity and Mach number are presented in absolute values. Thus, the reverse flow region at MFR = 0.24 appears as a positive bump attached at the bottom inlet wall (y = 0), even though the flow velocity is negative in this reverse region. MFR: mass flow ratio.
Losses are represented through the intake pressure recovery, defined as (14)Pressure recovery=Pt1Pt0

In the above equation Pt1 is the area-averaged total pressure at the intake highlight plane, while Pt0 the reference total pressure at infinity upstream. Figures 13 and 14 clearly show the effect of MFR on the flow field. Total pressure loss appears as a result of flow separation, represented by a low-pressure recovery in Figure 14. Furthermore, a flat region of total pressure appears, due to the upstream recirculation. For the sake of completeness, further plots of velocity and pressure recovery profiles of the ingested boundary layer for all the cases studied are presented in Appendix 3. Figure 14.
Boundary layer total pressure profiles at the intake throat for different MFRs, α = 2.6, M = 0.73, nacelle 1. MFR: mass flow ratio.

In order to assess inlet distortion, a new distortion coefficient is defined for rectangular intakes. It is based on the standard DC(60) which is defined as (15)DC(60)=Pt1-Pt60∘q0 where q0=1/2ρ0V0 2 is the reference dynamic head, Pt1 the area-averaged total pressure at the engine face and Pt60° the area-averaged total pressure of the worst circular sector of 60°. The new coefficient is based on the one-sixth of the total area, similar to DC(60°) which is based on the one-sixth of the total circular area. The new distortion coefficient is defined as (16)DC1/6=Pt1-Pt1/6q0 where, considering the full area partitioned along the vertical direction into six horizontal rectangles, Pt1/6 is the lowest area-averaged total pressure of these rectangles.

The variation of the pressure recovery and the distortion with MFR can be inferred from Figures 15 and 16. As shown in these figures, the reduction of MFR leads to flow separation that adds losses, reducing pressure recovery. In contrast to this, distortion index appears to reduce at low MFRs, as shown in Figure 16. The reason is that at high MFR, a substantial part of the area is undistorted, yielding a high value of averaged total pressure, which combined with low total pressure at the worst one-sixth of the area, gives rise to the distortion descriptor. On the other hand, at low MFR, the large separation reduces the average total pressure, leading to a lower distortion. It becomes then apparent that the pressure recovery and distortion are two complementing parameters, both requiring attention during the design process. Figure 15.
Pressure recovery with MFR. MFR: mass flow ratio.
Figure 16.
Distortion coefficient with MFR. MFR: mass flow ratio.

In the BLI propulsion system configuration, the boundary layer and therefore the total pressure loss ingested by the engine can be related to the drag ingested. This can be defined as the drag equivalent to the losses ingested by the engine.5,17,18 The drag ingested appears suitable to characterize BLI. In general, an increase of the drag ingested by the engine entails a propulsion efficiency raise. It is well known that obtaining accurate drag results from CFD is a complex issue.26 However, the calculation of the ingested drag is even more complex due to the problem configuration, see Appendix 2 for details of the drag-ingested calculation. Even though the drag-ingested errors from the CFD model may not be negligible, some important trends are clear and are explained in the following.

The non-dimensional drag-ingested coefficient can be read as (17)CD,ing=Ding1 2ρ0V0 2Sref where Ding is the drag ingested. It seems that for a constant MFR, related with a constant mass flow, the drag ingested increases with the pressure recovery reduction. As the boundary layer increases, the losses increase, there is a reduction in the velocities and the pressure recovery reduces, entailing a raise of the ingested drag. However, opposite occurs if the MFR reduces, the drag ingested decreases (Figure 17), despite the reduction of pressure recovery (Figure 15). With a MFR decrease, the mass flow entering the engine reduces and hence the drag ingested reduces as well since it is given by a mass flow integral. Therefore, with an MFR reduction, even though the losses increase and the specific drag ingested increases, the total drag ingested decreases, because of the total mass flow reduction. The low energy flow of the not ingested boundary layer is spilled around the nacelle, decreasing the overall system efficiency. This effect is very important because it could be thought at first sight that MFR reduction means more losses ingested and therefore propulsion efficiency improvements. However, it is shown that the drag ingested reduces and therefore an MFR reduction does not entail any beneficial effect regarding the losses ingested. Figure 17.

sec.title: Angle of attack
sec.p: The CFD model was run for two different angles of attack, α = 0° and 2.6°. The effect of the angle of attack on the pressure recovery can be inferred from Figure 15. Pressure recovery increases with angle of attack reduction, and for constant MFR, the losses produced over the airfoil are lower as the shock wave is weaker and the boundary layer thinner. The distortion is lower at zero angle of attack (Figure 16) as a result of the lower boundary layer height and amount of separation. In general, low angles of attack entail lower losses ingested (Figure 17). Nevertheless, lift increases with the angle of attack, as in any airfoil (Figure 10).

sec.title: Mach number
sec.p: The effect of Mach number is shown through two case studies, M = 0.73 and M = 0.66. The losses produced over the airfoil increase with Mach number. Therefore, more boundary layer is ingested and the total pressure recovery diminishes, as illustrated in Figure 15. Additionally, the drag ingested increases, (Figure 17), since the losses and the boundary layer thickness increase, and then the total pressure loss and the distortion increase, as shown in Figure 16. Furthermore, the lift improves with Mach number, as in a conventional airfoil (Figure 10).

sec.title: Intake height
sec.p: Two intake heights are compared, Hh = 0.3 m and Hh = 0.6 m. For the larger intake, there is a larger part of the non-distorted flow entering the engine. The distorted flow is, therefore, only a small part of the total flow ingested and, thus, the pressure recovery in Figure 15 is better since a larger portion of the area experiences a high total pressure. The distortion, however, is higher for the larger intake, as shown in Figure 16. The average total pressure of the whole area is higher for the larger intake, while the minimum total pressure is not much affected. As a result, distortion index is higher.

From Figure 10, it can be inferred that the smaller intake produces smaller disturbance in the flow upstream at low MFR as the lift coefficient is larger for the smaller intake. It should be noted, though, that at high MFR, the pre-entry diffusion is minimal, and therefore, the lift tends to the same value for both configurations.

It seems that the drag ingested is similar for both intakes at a MFR close to 1; however, it diminishes strongly for the larger intake than for the smaller one. In addition, the losses around the nacelle seem to increase more for the larger intake than for the smaller one at low MFR and tend to the same value for MFR close to 1.

In general, it can be concluded that a large intake under performs at low MFR, while it benefits from high-pressure recovery at very high values of MFR. It, therefore, appears that a good design should feature small enough nacelle height, but larger than the height of the boundary layer, in order to avoid spillage of low kinetic energy flow of the not ingested boundary layer, which would lead to a system efficiency reduction.

sec.title: Nacelle length
sec.p: Two different nacelle lengths are studied, namely L = 1.7 m and L = 0.85 m. The length of the nacelle offsets the axial position of the intake highlight plane on the airfoil, as engine exhaust plane is positioned at the trailing edge.

The pressure recovery is lower for the short installation (Figure 15), since the engine ingests a more developed boundary layer, which also entails a drag-ingested increase, as shown in Figure 17. Nonetheless, distortion is lower for the shorter nacelle (Figure 16).

The lift is higher for the shorter nacelle, intake positioned closer to aft, as a larger area is available for the lift developing suction zone, while it is less affected by the pre-compression streamtube.

sec.title: Conclusions
sec.p: A 2D computational study of the effects of a BLI propulsion system on the wing aerodynamics of a BWB aircraft in transonic flow has been carried out. The agreement of the CFD model of the airfoil RAE 2822 with the experimental results provided in Cook et al.22 is found to be excellent and, therefore, the CFD approach is used as a base to assess the aerodynamic performance of the BLI propulsion system. The MFR of the engine is varied while useful conclusions have been derived with regard to the effect of angle of attack, Mach number, intake height and nacelle length on significant variables involved in the aircraft design and performance.

A point to be taken into further consideration is the close coupling between engine and wing, shown through the strong effect of MFR on the aerodynamic behaviour of the airfoil. Low MFR leads to a boundary layer growth and even to separation with a recirculation region, losses in total pressure and therefore to a reduction of pressure recovery decreasing the quality of the flow entering the engine. Moreover, the drag ingested by the engine reduces as well, spilling the low-energy flow around the nacelle and thus reducing the benefits of BLI. Notice that this low MFR spillage is stronger than in a standard engine configuration. In addition, low MFR has a very negative effect on the overall wing lift.

It is also found that higher angles of attack lead to a thick boundary layer, lower pressure recovery and therefore more drag ingested. As for a standard airfoil, larger angles of attack entails higher lift, provided there is no boundary layer separation. Similarly, a Mach number increase produces more lift, but also lower pressure recovery and losses ingested as well as a higher distortion.

The study of the engine nacelle geometry effects has shown that at high MFR, a large intake presents better behaviour in terms of pressure recovery. However, at low MFR, large intake performance declines as the ingested losses reduce, spilling the low-energy flow around the nacelle in addition to a lift decrease. Then, it becomes evident that the choice of inlet height must be the result of a careful design. It is also shown that the intake plane is better positioned at the aft. Shorter nacelles ingest more boundary layer, increasing the drag ingested, while higher lift can be achieved since the suction zone upstream the engine is larger.

The boundary layer ingesting propulsion system is found to open new possibilities for a more efficient flight. Nevertheless, the complexity of the BLI system and the blending of lift and propulsion systems aerodynamics makes it a very sensitive configuration, as has been highlighted in this study. This article provides a preliminary insight into the behaviour of significant variables linked to the general aircraft performance and system efficiency. The study has clarified several relevant considerations to be taken into account in the design process of such propulsion system, where a multi-objective optimization should ensure the optimum combination of the design parameters to achieve maximum benefits from this emerging technology.

sec.title: Drag ingested
sec.p:
The viscosity losses produced in the boundary layer developed over the airfoil and ingested by the engine create a total pressure loss at engine entrance (Figure 14), at the station 1 defined in Figure 18. This total pressure loss, Pt1/Pt0 < 1, is related to loss in kinetic energy and thus to an equivalent drag, which is the drag ingested Ding. The drag, by its definition, needs to be calculated between two stations at same static pressure. As the flow at the station 1 is not at free-stream static pressure p0, it is required to expand isentropically the variables of the station 1 to the free-stream static pressure p0 = p01 in order to be able to evaluate the drag ingested as a loss in momentum between two stations at the same static pressure. Thus, the drag ingested can be defined as follows (18)Ding=∫A01(V0-V01)V01ρ01dA 01 Figure 18.
BLI stations with the new station 01 isentropically expanded from station 1.

The area A01 is not known, and therefore, it is not possible to integrate there. However, knowing that the whole streamtube from the station 1 to 01 has the same mass flow and is compound of infinite differential streamtubes in which continuity can be applied, the infinitesimal mass flow continuity follows as (19)dW 01=ρ01V01dA 01=ρ1V1dA 1=dW 1⇒dA 01=ρ1V1ρ01V01dA 1

Using this in eqaution (18), the integral for the drag can be rewritten as (20)Ding=∫A01(V0-V01)V01ρ01ρ1V1ρ01V01dA 1=∫A1(V0-V01)ρ1V1dA 1 which is a mass flow integral of the expanded velocity V01 at the engine entrance. The equivalent expanded velocity V01 for each point at the engine entrance A1 is calculated from the expanded Mach number M01 using the isentropic equations of total pressure and temperature at the stations 1 and 01, and assuming ideal gases. Knowing that the total pressure and total temperature are constant for the isentropic expansion (no losses), Pt1 = Pt01 and Tt1 = Tt01, the Mach number M01 comes to (21)M01=2γ-1 (Pt1p0γ-1γ-1 )

Using the Mach number and total temperature, the static temperature can be read as (22)t01=T1 (1+γ-1 2M01 2 ) and applying the Mach definition the expanded velocity V01 at each point at the station 1 is calculated as (23)V01=M01γRt01 Having the corresponding expanded velocity V01 for each point at the engine entrance, the station 1, the drag ingested is calculated using equation (20). In addition, using the mass flow average of the expanded velocity V01, the propulsive efficiency can be calculated from equation (2).
